dict.string:
LTE Advanced supports the concept of relaying at base station level in order to extend network coverage and scale capacity. A relay node (RN) connects to the core network via another base station, called a Donor eNodeB. The RN is wirelessly connected to the DeNB via a slightly modified LTE radio interface called the Un interface. The DeNB may also support direct connection to UEs like any other base station in addition to the RNs.

There are two types of RNs – Type 1 & Type 2. A Type 1 RN creates its own radio cell different from the cells of the DeNB and acts an independent base station for the UE. A Type 2 RN on the other hand can’t create its own radio cell and just extends the coverage of the DeNB cells like a repeater. The RN may be connected to the DeNB using the same radio frequency as used for communication with UE or a different frequency. In the case of former, simultaneous transmission from UE to RN and from RN to DeNB and vice-versa in downlink may not be possible due to interference.

Key benefits include:

  • Extends radio coverage and scale capacity
  • A RN behaves like a UE to DeNB so existing radio protocols can be used with some modifications

• 3GPP Release 8 & 9 Compliant -Trillium Software for 3G/4G/LTE
  • Trillium TOTALeNodeB Solution

• LTE E-UTRAN and its Access Side Protocols
  • LTE - Top 12 Challenges
